title: Shazam! Fury of the Gods
description: Billy Batson and his foster siblings, who transform into superheroes by saying "Shazam!", are forced to get back into action and fight the Daughters of Atlas, who they must stop from using a weapon that could destroy the world.

reviews.text: Fury of the Gods wasn't really that great. The story feels like a series of sketches that miss cohesion. I think the premise was really good, but the execution and writing was poor. The fast dialogues (way too fast at time) and forced jokes broke the rhythm a lot. I didn't feel invested in the characters because I didn't have time to do so. The CGI were a bit better then the first movie. But I couldn't help seeing some Green Lantern effects in there.  The acting was unequal but that was to be expected. But the movie focus too much on Freddy for my taste, and they gave him hyper fast dialogues, that didn't favour his character. The villains were' I don't know...just there. The music and sounds were ok. I give it 53%. All the personal stuff is briefly skimmed and never truly explored. It's an action movie with barely any intelligible humour and any convincing drama.

Typical film for children, at all times they want to put a joke and a humor that is embarrassing, it makes sense why the film is for children, since the heroes are children.  Of course not forgetting the love of a young man of 15 years with a goddess of 6000... would it be pedophilia?

Good popcorn film, nothing more... But there are no surprises: generic monsters, generic villains, generic action in generic super-hero film... I'm little disappointed with this sequel... Lot of bad jokes. Long product placement for Skittles. Cheap cameos. Still quite fun and watchable, I like this family dynamic... Anyway, the big reboot is coming so why we should care? And no: it's not "Superhero Film Fatigue" - it's "Bad CGI and Mediocre Story Fatigue"!

Não dá pra exigir muito de um filme cuja proposta claramente é fazer rir, tratando seus personagens de forma idiotizadas, típico filme feito para não se levar muito a sério. Nesse sentido, ao menos podemos dizer que ele é eficiente.Não me canso de dizer que filmes infantis não precisam ser necessariamente idiotices puras. Temos aí filmes da Pixar/Disney para comprovar. Mas também não quer dizer que necessariamente precisam ser profundos. Está tudo bem criar roteiros pífios como aqui e se entregar a diversão.Há, no entanto, muitos e muitos furos, além de incontáveis momentos em que, por exemplo, a vilã poderia acabar com tudo e fica conversando por vários minutos até vir alguém e desarmar. O roteiro beira o amadorismo, e o maniqueísmo de quem é bom ou mau beira o ridículo, sem contar que uma das personagens muda instantaneamente, sem pudor algum.A DC aqui pega o que há de pior nos filmes da Marvel e insere em duas horas de projeção. Se você for com o mínimo desejo de ver uma boa história, melhor não ir, e se você não curte piadas bobinhas, aí mesmo que deve passar longe.Ainda bem que eu fui assistir de coração leve e muito bem tranquilo com o material, por isso não me arrependi tanto assim, consegui até mesmo dar boas risadas, ainda que entrasse fácil como um dos piores do ano.

"Shazam! Fury of the Gods" was...  Kind of a letdown.  As a huge Shazam fan, I went into this movie with the utmost positivity, but my upbeat optimism was dashed by this films lack of focus.  None of the events in this movie seemed to flow naturally and everything was just happening off of a conveyor belt.  This, coupled with some VERY unthreatening, non-canon, movie exclusive antagonist's, made for an experience that seemed more like filler than anything else.  Speaking of the antagonists of this film, Helen Mirren and Lucy Liu did an excellent job in their roles as Hespera and Kalypso and were definitely the stand outs, but even their combine powers of brilliant thespianism were no match for the evil that is DCEU's knack for fumbling their films.There was at least one scene at the end of the movie that was kinda cool, but it really doesn't make up for the rest of the movies inability to "wow" me.  This was not what I would call a "worthy sequel" to the first Shazam movie.  Not only does it pale in comparison to the original, but it will more than likely dissipate from most peoples memories shortly after they’ve watched it.
It’s just so ugly and mostly unfunny. I think Levi is solid in the role, but the writing is lazy, creating easy ways to get out of situations within a scene. DCEU reboot can’t come soon enough.
It felt stupid and it is stupid, the plot is completely incoherent at best. RIP to the Shazamverse and I greatly await you (not) returning to the new DC era.

It advances in matters of scale, but regresses enormously in matters of plot and there wasn't much there in the first place, but I must say that Shazam! Fury of the Gods borders at many points on a line that almost makes it a children's film.The constant need for humor clouds any attempt at seriousness and only manages to get a touch of drama in its climax that frankly doesn't add up to anything.The show entertains for the most part, but considering the reboot that's coming, Shazam gives no reason to stick around in the DCEU. A shame.* Though the first post-credits scene gives a minuscule hint that maybe James Gunn does have him considered for what's to come. But like I said it's minuscule.** And only for a small mention. More enjoyable for me than the reviews led me to believe.  Another movie with at least eight director-level collaborators:  a 2nd unit director plus seven VFX directors one for each house working pre, post and during production.  When so many people who love telling stories well collaborate, the result is almost always impressive on multiple levels.  As regularly happens in pro reviews of most super hero movies, the Great Expectations pattern takes over.  The final movie is criticized for what it is not; and, for what it could have been.  This is the fast way to become a jaded and cynical movie reviewer.  I recommend finding the moments which do work for you, try to ignore the rest on first viewing.  As the negative pro reviews observe, Shazam 2 is very much a movie with a 2010 mindset, perseverating on familiar tropes which ran out of oomph a decade or more ago.  I did not find Helen Mirren and Lucy Liu "bland." I did find the stereotyped limitations of their roles and dialog very 1990s. The most literate, considered pro reviews on S2 Ive seems so far are from Owen Gleiberman in Variety and Jacob Oller at Paste.
